description: This course will explore the major processes of government and non-profit financial management including budgeting(operating and capital), revenue estimation(tax and non-tax), long and short term cash management, long and short term debt management, and accounting (income statements and balance sheets). During this exploration, the tools of finance will be used including present value, future value, net present value, internal rate of return, amortization, yield and price of securities. The student will leave the coursean ability to understand and analyze complex financial transactions including bond issues, development pro forma, and cost benefit models. The course is part of a new minor on Budgeting, Finance, Leadership, and Teamwork (B-FLAT Minor),now being developed by the College of Arts and Sciences. It will be a core requirement and will count for the minor when it is approved.
